newsitem.title: INDONESIA: General Electric sees Indonesia as key.
newsitem.headline: General Electric sees Indonesia as key.

text.p: U.S. giant General Electric Co said on Wednesday that it saw Indonesia as the lynchpin of its southeast Asian operations and planned a major increase in its presence there by the turn of the century.

"We continue to be impressed with the progress of the Indonesian economy. The investment policies continue to liberalise," Stuart Dean, president of General Electric Indonesia, told a news conference.

"If you look at the economic growth in combination with the declining inflation rate, Indonesia perhaps has the best economic components in ASEAN this year," Dean said while announcing a new joint venture between General Electric Lighting Indonesia and local firm PT Sinar Baru Electric.

Paul Morse, who will head the new venture, PT GE Lighting Indonesia, said that the company was already using Indonesia as a base from which to serve the consumer market in ASEAN, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and planned to expand this role in the future.
"Our strategy is for our Indonesian business to serve the rest of ASEAN as well as Australia and already to date we have been shipping to those countries," said Morse.
ASEAN groups Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
As well as lighting, Dean said he hoped that all twelve of General Electric's core businesses would have investments in Indonesia by the turn of the century.
"At the moment only six of our units have investments here. By the end of the century, I hope all 12 can be invested," Dean said.
"We are very bullish on Indonesia's long-term economics and anticipate being a bigger player in the future," he added.
When asked about riots in Jakarta in July, seen by many analysts as a deterrent to investing in the country, Dean said he was unperturbed.
"In developing countries there are going to be some bumps along the road in their development," he said

"But if you are a long-term global player, you need to be in the (world's) fourth-most populous country that is growing at 8 percent a year...that is seeing a middle class of 30-40 million people growing at 15-20 percent a year."

Dean said that General Electric has been involved in Indonesia since 1950 but only recently had investment growth started to boom. Investment over the past five years was approximately $200 billion in the six businesses operating in the country, he said.

In industries like lighting, however, Morse conceded that General Electric had to catch up on competition. Dutch firm Philips Electronics NV is already a household name in Indonesia, whereas GE's Surabaya factory was only opened in 1994.
